author: Scott Podmore
title: Six great restaurants to visit in Nashville, Tennessee
text:
MUSIC is what usually draws people to Nashville for the first time. Creative personalities from all over the world have joined forces in Music City since the 1920s and the result has been pure magic.
But there’s something more these days. A perfect storm of chef-driven eateries and high expectations has inspired a surge of interest in Southern cooking traditions with a modern touch to relaunch Music City with another tagline – Food City.
A burgeoning culinary scene is striking a chord with Nashvillains and luring in a new breed of travellers.
“There’s a lot to love about Nashville’s creative vibe,” says hometown boy Patrick, a waiter from The Farm House on Almond St in Downtown – a paddock-to-plate spot drawing foodies from far and wide.
“We’ve gone way past the standard ‘meat and three’ and fried chicken dripping in oil. There’s a sophistication and intelligence with the Nashville food scene nowadays, it’s progressing and becoming as important as the music.”
Halfway back to the kitchen with our orders, Patrick turns and waxes lyrical in timely fashion.
“The food sings, too, you see.”
Patrick was well on the way to a meaty tip from six Aussie APT guests soaking up the Southern hospitality.
While the boot-scootin’ rumble and good-time music jam reverberates out of the crowded, neon-lit honky-tonks at every 10 paces, it’s just as important to know where the best food haunts are.
Here are six to consider:
 The Farm House pork belly. Source: Supplied
THE FARM HOUSE
YOU’VE already met smooth-talking Patrick, but say hello to The Farm House’s creator, chef and entrepreneur Trey Cioccia, who opened the restaurant a year ago.
“Oh yeah, we’re ready,” Cioccia says. “Nashville has well and truly arrived for food. Especially our farm-to-fork approach here.”
So, what to eat? Try a starter of double devilled eggs with ham and smoked salt, before tearing through the rib-eye served with mushrooms and turnips, red wine, cipollini onion, salad, jus and a tomato gravy, or the Rabbit Three Ways, chicken-fry confit haunch, seared confit breast or the grilled tenderloin with flageolet beans and crouton tossed with charred celeriac and black garlic puree.
The Farm House’s decor standout is the restored barn wood, Tennessee heirlooms and modern touches with lighting.
It’s a restaurant with heart, too. Military past and present receive half-price meals “always and forever”, says Cioccia.
thefarmhousetn.com
HUSK
Authentic Southern food at its best on Rutledge St is popular for a constantly changing menu.
We started with a choice of cocktails (under $10) and a serve of Shrimp and Grits, then munched on Crispy Pig Ears and tackled a main of pork, potatoes, cabbage as well as shiitake mushrooms catfish with brussels sprouts, chestnuts and apple.
husknashville.com
THE STOCK-YARD
It’s been named as one of the top 10 steakhouses in the US – and for good reason. The Stock-Yard has been satisfying the appetites of natives for more than 35 years, dishing up certified Angus beef, lobster, fresh seafood and ribs in a rustic, historic setting where quirky and heritage stockyard memorabilia adorns the walls.
This one’s hard to top for Nashville dining with a point of difference. Your dining experience may be enhanced or diminished, depending on your musical taste, by a flash appearance of a country music artist slipping in for a few tunes to entertain guests.
stock-yardrestaurant.com
ROLF AND DAUGHTERS
This northern Italian restaurant in Taylor St finds the balance of infusing Southern ingredients with delectable dishes that include rigatoni lamb, taleggio tortellini and farro spaghetti.
There’s a sense of adventure in the food, too, including seaweed butter on sourdough or scarlet turnips with yoghurt and fennel or the dry aged beef tartare, smoked mussels, chickpea and toast.
In the two years it’s been open, Rolf and Daughters has carved out a reputation as the best Italian eatery in Nashville.
rolfanddaughters.com
 Nashville, Tennessee skyline on the Cumberland River. Picture: iStock Source: Supplied
THE PHARMACY BURGER PARLOUR & BEER GARDEN
Voted Nashville’s No.1 burger haunt two years running, The Pharmacy on McFerrin Ave uses 100 per cent Tennessee-raised beef for its burgers and claims to boast the “hardest-working kitchen that grinds, stuffs and smokes every wurst (sausage) that we serve”, according to its staff.
The sausage options are outstanding, offering up every “wurst” you can think of, including Bratwurst, Currywurst and Jagerwurst, the latter being a pork sausage mixed with coriander, garlic, mustard, nutmeg and ginger.
The beer garden is a noisy, happy place and non-drinkers can indulge in an old-school soda fountain serving milkshakes and ice cream sodas.
thepharmacynashville.com
HATTIE B’S HOT CHICKEN
For the more traditional Southern experience on the cheap, Hattie B’s is a hit with the Nashville natives, so loosen your belt and stroll down 19th Ave for a classic serve of deep fried Southern chicken with a side of black-eyed pea salad.
Be warned, the “Cluckin’ hot” spice mix option will test your resilience. If there’s room left, sink your fangs into a Peach Cobbler or Banana Pudding.
hattieb.com
The writer was a guest of APT.

FAST FACTS
Prince’s Hot Chicken, the first and most well-known hot chicken restaurant, began when Thornton Prince’s girlfriend suspected him of cheating on her so she put extra pepper in his fried chicken. Thornton liked it so much that he opened the BBQ Chicken Shack in the mid-1930s that would later become Prince’s Hot Chicken.
Goo Goos, Nashville’s famous candy, is made of chocolate, caramel, marshmallows and peanuts.
